body:
Thanks @jkff, I've already applied your test suggestions. 
We are using our custom Kinesis source prepared for Dataflow SDKs and it autoscales reasonably with Kinesis. It uses exactly the same logic as proposed in https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/3551. So I can confirm that this approach should be fine here.

Hi @lukecwik , there are 2 use cases:

1. being able to start a pipeline from a EE container (which requires to pass the basic serialization validation)
2. being able to implement a transform with a custom classloader (the PTransform + impl loader is in the classpath but not the actual impl with its dependencies) to isolate conflicting stacks used in the same job.

This small patch makes at least simple cases working well.
Since https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/3851 is already merged, we can proceed with this one. I've rebased this PR on top of master and removed TODO comment. @jkff could you please take a look?

It used to be that the generated code for proto2 in c++ didn't allow for the same enum name to exist within the same proto definition because all enums were siblings and not children of the declared enum types. Will need to double check this before accepting your suggestion.
If proto3 has the same issue, we need to rewrite all of our enums to prefix them. So it is harmless to follow the current pattern here.

It does look like protoc for C++ dumps enums into the parent namespace: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/cpptutorial#enums-and-nested-classes

The same is true for Python:https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/pythontutorial#enums

For clarity, the overall you have here and the one that prefixes all our enums should be in separate commits.
@reuvenlax Did you mean to also approve this?

Yep, just saw the email, `mvn clean verify` in progress right now

edit: all up to date now, merge looks clean

this is great. one comment: I would prefer if the files went into their own directory (perhaps named website_snippets or something?) similar to the python snippets, so the files aren't floating around in the main examples directory.

The configuration looks OK, but I agree that if possible you should use shading rather than add the properties file. Taking a peek at the contents of the jar is helpful.

I am surprised there are no changes to the `BeamSqlApiSurfaceTest`. That makes me think the test wasn't working.

Taking a look, you probably want a couple more surface tests. The test you have is OK for ensuring that the actual public API surface is still going to work, but it does not ensure that you don't have forbidden residual dependencies.

I actually think it needs to be an IT to operate on the shaded jar, right? And then it should test `ApiSurface.ofPackage(...)` to ensure that Guava & Calcite do not appear anywhere.

To add some more context: 

 - Some API surface tests check the current class's classloader. I think this was an attempt to get transitive dependencies. I don't recall how it works but I worry it might miss things.
 - Testing the whole package is better than a particular class or selection of classes. If you use Guava and Calcite on `public` methods it is going to fail. That isn't really wrong - you have shaded things on public API. So you need to whitelist/exclude subpackages and classes that are marked `@Internal`. If this is too hard, then communicating what is the real API to users is also too hard.

let's summary the discussions together:

1. the shade configuration

I intent to include that file. If we want to avoid it, I suppose [my previous comment](https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/3848#issuecomment-331959232) is one option, which would package a non-relocated class file `org.codehaus.janino.CompilerFactory`; --Please share if other solutions;

2. add IT test

Is [WordCountIT](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/examples/java/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/examples/WordCountIT.java) the right example? I think [BeamSqlExample](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/example/BeamSqlExample.java) can be used. Thoughts?

3. API surface

The existing test lists the 4 public classes, except `org.apache.beam.sdk.extensions.sql.impl` which are internal classes regarding to implementation. --I'm not sure whether it can cover the scenarios of shade.
CC @xumingming for more comments

@jasonkuster Do you know if the two PreCommits should currently pass?

Its hard to do an apples-apples comparison here because the model is so different between `read` and `readGenericRecords`, but I did a trivial test of reading ~100 million rows from a BQ table and summing one field of them.  I used 5 dataflow workers (default configuration) w/o autoscaling enabled.

The table was 96,470,755 rows, and BQ reported it to be 19.4 GB.

Read Method | Wall time* | Throughput** | Bytes processed*** | size increase/(decrease)
--------------|-----------|-------------|--------------------|----------------------
`read()`          | 15:39        | ~140,000    | 163.61 GB                | 8.5x
`readGenericRecords()` | 7:49 | ~700,000 | 1.71 GB               | (11)x

\* Wall time = time from job starting to the last step completing.
** In rows per second, measured from the input to the `Sum` PTransform.
*** Bytes processed measured at the input to the step after the read transform

The two flows are here: https://gist.github.com/steveniemitz/c6de0b7f6dbfbee53e812956a4f5476a
So what's left here? Do we still need more tests?
